head.title: Journal of a Passage in a Canoe from Pais Plat in Lake Superior to Portage de l'Isle in River Ouinipique, 1784. - Page #23

body.p: << First Page | < Previous Page | Page #23 of 32 | Next Page > | Last Page >>

td.p: Umfreville, Edward. Journal of a Passage in a Canoe from Pais Plat in Lake Superior to Portage de l'Isle in River Ouinipique, 1784. An electronic transcription. MFTP #0030

div.p: to a Strait – in it ¾m. to a Rapid, pass'd it easily – then left an Isld on Lt & took a narrow Channel on Rt – 300yds to another rapid, pass'd it as before, then a lac Co – 3m to a pt on Rt a high pt of woods laying opposite, then coast'd along same shore 1½m. to a pt passing a small rocky I. on Lt – then Travers'd 1½ to a rocky pt on Lt a small Isld opposite to it & bay on Rt Co NWbW – then turn'd ye pt & went Wt ¾ to a rocky pt on Lt then to a rock on Lt WbS3m. pass'd an Isld on Lt – then WSW3m. to a high pt on Lt appearing like a narrow Strait, but afterwds into a River from the Strait mentd turn'd upon ye Rt & went 8m. to a lac, in wch SW3 to a lofty pt of an Isld on Lt pass'd a deep bay on each side – coasted along the Isle abt ¾ – from it SW1½ to a low rocky pt on Rt passing 2 small Isld on Lt – from thence to a grassy pt on same side near ¼ – turn'd ye Grassy pt & travers'd ½m. to a pt on Lt – turn'd ye pt & entd a river again & went 1m. to a Rapid, shot it by leaving 1 small I on Rt & anr near it on Lt then went SbW to a pt on Lt 1m. then 2½m. farther to Port. de l'Isle 22yds over a rock, being a small Isle in the middle of the River (NB The Guide says this is the 1st time that ever the Canads pass'd this Cataract in this manner, the usual manner being to discharge on a rock on the Rt & make a Port. on the main, which Port. he says is called La Pante) abt 20yds from which 2 small Islets, shot the remainder of the rapid leavg ye 2 Is on ye Lt – ¼m. to Port. Galais, near 70yds over a Rock, from the end of this Port. SEbS1½ to Portage à la Pointe 46yds over a rock, Port. on Rt side & Isld on Lt in ye mid. of the Channel – from ye Port. into a Lac. Co from ye Port. SSW½ to ye smooth rocky pt of an Isld on Rt then SW2m. to a traverse to the pt of a small rocky Isle on Lt lac spacious to ye Rt – then same Co to an openg which appears like a River dist. 2m. – turn'd ye pt on Lt & entd a river again, passing a small rocky I. on Rt & leaving a long streight view behind us, went in it 2½m. to a rapid passing it on Lt side – then 5¾ to a small lac, cross'd it SSE1m. to a Strait, in it ¼ to the extreme pt on Rt – then entd a lac – turn'd ye pt on Rt & went WSW1m. to a pt on Lt / a long view to the left entg ye Lac leaving a rocky Isld on Rt – turn'd ye pt & Travers'd SWbW3½ to a low pt on Rt pass'[d] 4 large Is on Lt & 1 on Rt – then WSW1¼ to a pt of Stones[.] (Here we found ye Chi[ef] mentd ye 18th with anr Chief & 3 young men, who had a fine Stock of Deer's flesh & which they were desirous of Trading, this was most acceptable to us as the men had began upon their last Sack of Corn. The old man who had return'd affected much regard for me as being a Sagonosh, & was honour'd in an extraordinary manner by their discharging their Fuzees – these Inds & those who we left on the 17th promis'd me that in case I wintd hereabouts they would trade their furs with me, & I have some reasons to think 'em sincère.[)]

July 21 Wednesday. (On examing the meat traded yesterday, I find we have full allowance for 4 days witht touching the Corn[.]) The pt of Stones mentd yesterday is the beginning of a wide Strait with a very strong Currt went in it ¼ to Port. la Chut[te] 170yds over a rock on Rt side, the place for reloading the Canoe is exceeding bad the water being much agitated by the Rapid – from the Port. entd a lac, turn'd ye 1st pt on Lt ½m. in lac spacious with Is on Rt – then cross'd a bay on same side 1½[m] havg a rocky I. on Rt – then cross'd a bay to a Strait WSW2m. deep bay on Rt

td.p:
L E G E N D :
in red , modifications made by the editor(s).
in lavender , modifications made by the assumed author(s).
